Article.ArticleTitle: Using spatio-temporal modeling for exposure assessment in an investigation of fine particulate air pollution and cardiovascular mortality.

AbstractText: U.S. urban air quality has improved dramatically over the past decades. We evaluated acute effects of fine particulate matter (PM<sub>2.5</sub>) on cardiovascular (CVD) mortality among residents of Allegheny County in SW Pennsylvania (1999-2011) using spatio-temporal modeling of air pollutants (AP) to reduce misclassification error in exposure assessment.

Spatio-temporal kriging of daily PM<sub>2.5</sub> and ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) was used to produce daily exposure estimates at the residence ZIP code. Time-stratified case-crossover analysis was conducted to examine short-term effects of PM<sub>2.5</sub> on CVD mortality, adjusting for O<sub>3</sub> and apparent mean temperature. We studied both single and distributed lags for days 0-5. All CVD mortality and subcategories of ischemic heart disease (IHD), acute myocardial infarction, cerebrovascular disease, peripheral vascular disease (PVD), heart failure and cardiac arrhythmia were examined.

A total of 62,135 deaths were identified. We found significant associations of PM<sub>2.5</sub> with IHD and PVD mortality at lag day 5: (2.1% (95% CI, 0.2-4.1%) and (7.6%, 95% CI, 0.05-15.7%) per 10µg/m<sup>3</sup> increase of PM<sub>2.5</sub> in single lag models and for IHD in distributed lag models. There were no statistically significant associations with PM<sub>2.5</sub> for any of the other outcomes.

The application of finer scale geographically resolved AP exposures made it possible to study acute effects of PM<sub>2.5</sub> on CVD mortality in a large metropolitan area. Our study results demonstrated the continued presence of a dose response relationship of increased risk of CVD mortality within this lower range of PM<sub>2.5</sub> exposure.
